Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Situation2: Going to the gym to maintain physical fitness
Story: I was lacing up my sneakers, ready to hit the gym for my daily workout—something I couldn’t skip as a police officer. Physical fitness wasn’t just about looking good; it was about being able to protect people, to do my job right. Just as I grabbed my keys, my phone buzzed. It was Sam, my old friend. “Hey, can you hop on a quick video call? I’m losing my mind with this furniture. The instructions make no sense.” I could hear the frustration in his voice. He’d always been there for me, and I knew he was counting on me now, even for something as small as this. But I also knew that skipping my workout meant letting down my duty to stay sharp and ready for the job. My mind raced—should I be the friend Sam needed right now, or the officer my community expected? The weight of both roles pressed on me, and I stood frozen, phone in hand, torn between two worlds.
